review.title: The Diverse Cohort Selection Problem: Multi-Armed Bandits with Varied Pulls
review.abstract: How should a firm allocate its limited interviewing resources to select the optimal cohort of new employees from a large set of job applicants? How should that firm allocate cheap but noisy resume screenings and expensive but in-depth in-person interviews? We view this problem through the lens of combinatorial pure exploration (CPE) in the multi-armed bandit setting, where a central learning agent performs costly exploration of a set of arms before selecting a final subset with some combinatorial structure. We generalize a recent CPE algorithm to the setting where arm pulls can have different cost, but return different levels of information, and prove theoretical upper bounds for a general class of arm-pulling strategies in this new setting. We then apply our general algorithm to a real-world problem with combinatorial structure: incorporating diversity into university admissions. We take real data from admissions at one of the largest US-based computer science graduate programs and show that a simulation of our algorithm produced more diverse student cohorts at low cost to individual student quality, and does so by spending comparable budget to the current admissions process at that university.

sections.text: How should a company, school, or scholarship allocate its limited interview resources to select the optimal cohort of new employees, students, or laureates from a large group of applicants? Here, the central decision-maker must first form a belief in the true quality of a candidate, and then select a subset of applicants that maximize a larger amount of information. In addition, various types of information-gathering can be performed - resuming, scheduling an interview, flying a candidate out for a full-day interview, and so on - to collect larger amounts of information, but also, most importantly, not affecting the overall usability of a cohort.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments
sections.text: In this section, the SWAP algorithm is experimentally validated using a variety of arm-pull strategies, starting with the concrete concretization of a submodular objective function (§ 5.1) that promotes diversity in the final cohort selected by the algorithm, followed by the simulation (§ 5.2) of the effectiveness of our limits in Theorem 3 and Logical Sequence 2.1, and finally applying SWAP to real-world data (§ 5.3) derived from one of the largest computer science graduate programs in the United States. We show a significant increase in diversity with little loss of adaptation and the same resource consumption as in practice.

sections.heading: 5.1 Formally Promoting the Diversity of a Cohort
sections.text: The SWAP algorithm presented in Section 4 is defined in the context of a generic submodular and monotonous oracle; in practice, domain experts would determine an appropriate function to maximize it. Motivated by recent evidence that diversity in the workplace can increase productivity (Hunt, Layton and Prince 2015; Desrochers 2001), in this section we examine the impact of formally promoting diversity in cohort selection. Quantifying the diversity of a number of elements is of interest in a variety of areas, including recommendation systems, information query, computer vision and others (Liu, Suel and Memon 2014; Qin and Zhu 2013; Ashkan et al. 2015; Sha, Wu and Niu 2016; Radlinski, Kleinberg and Joachims 2008; Ahmed, Dickerson and Fuge 2017).

sections.heading: 5.3 Graduate Admissions Experiment
sections.text: The experiment was approved by the university's Institutional Review Board, while the data from the last academic year was used to evaluate SWAP's performance (treated as a test set).Dataset. During the admissions process, potential students from around the world were sent into their application interviews. A single application consists of quantitative information such as GPA, GRE scores, TOEFL scores, nationality, previous degrees and so on, as well as qualitative information in the form of letters of recommendation and explanation of purpose. In recent academic years, we received approximately 1,600 applications, with approximately 4,500 applications over every three years. The most recent 1,600 applications are roughly divided into 1,000 applicants seeking admission and 600 female students applying.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we modeled the allocation of interview resources and the subsequent selection of a cohort of applicants as a combinatorial pure exploration problem in multi-arm bandit setting. We generalized an up-to-date CPE algorithm to the setting in which arm pulls can have different costs - that is, in which a decision maker can perform strong and weak pull movements, the former costing more than the latter, but also leading to a less loud signal. We presented the strong-weak arm pulse (SWAP) algorithm and proven theoretical limits for a general class of arm pulls strategies in this setting. In addition, we provided simulation results to test the density of these limits. We then applied SWAP to a real problem with combinatorial structure: the inclusion of diversity in university admissions. In real admissions data from one of the largest US-based computer studies passports, we showed that SWAP would reduce the quality of current SWAP for both the diversity of student cohorts and the low cost of university admissions.
